conclusion: The diaphragm starts to leak when the pressure difference between the two chambers equals the weight of the diaphragm.
Set up the equation: p1 V1 = p2 V2 + mg, where p1 and p2 are pressures in the upper and lower chambers, and V1 and V2 are their respective volumes.
The total volume of the cylinder is 2V, so V1 + V2 = 2V.
The pressure difference when the diaphragm starts to leak is expressed as p1 - p2 = mg/A.
Calculate cross-sectional area A as V/H, given the volume of the cylinder is 2V and height is 2H.
Substitute A into the pressure difference equation to get p1 - p2 = mgH/V.
Substitute the pressure difference expression into the forces equation: p1 V1 = p2 V2 + mg.
Substitute p1 = p2 = p into the equation to get p V1 = p (2V - V1) + mgV/H.
Simplify the equation to get 2V1 = 2V + mgV/pH.
Solve for V1 to get V1 = V + mgV/2pH.
Calculate the volume of the lower chamber V2 as 2V - V1 = V - mgV/2pH.
Substitute x into the equation for V2 to get V2 = V - xV/2.
Determine the volume of the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak as V0 = V(1 - x/2).
